intro: Tragacantha fasciculifolia, commonly known as the Persian gum plant, is a flowering plant native to the Middle East and parts of Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces a resinous gum, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Its growth habit includes both shrub and tree forms, depending on environmental conditions. Tragacantha fasciculifolia is adapted to arid and semi-arid climates, making it a resilient species in harsh environments.
